name: 800 Junior
keyboard: Full stroke 75 key with 5 function keys and arrow keys
colors: 8 with two tones each (normal and bright)
ports: tape recorder, TV/RF modulator, video RGB, video mono, joystick (mouse, light pen), Parallel Centronics, serial RS-232C, FDD (in 800-3)
description:
The Elwro 800 series was designed in 1985 by people from the Automatics
Institute of Technical University in Poznan, following the request of
Polish Ministry of Education.

The final product had to be:
? Cheap,
? ZX Spectrum compatible,
? Appropriate for school use.

The computer went into production in 1986 in Elwro Electronic Factory
of Wroclaw, Poland. It was fully Spectrum compatible. Designers also added network capability to access the shared printers and floppy drives.

The operating system was CP/J, a modified version of CP/M allowing networks called Junet to be managed. The 800 Junior could could work under the CP/M 2.2.

The funny thing is the computer case was taken from a toy piano. The wire on the top of the case was used initially as a music stand...

Planned production volume for 1986 was 500 pieces.

Elwro 800 Junior was released in three different versions:
Elwro 800, the "student" version had no disk controller,
Elwro 800-2, the "teacher" version had a disk controller,
Elwro 800-3 was a off-line version students or teachers could use.

In 1990, a Junior 804 prototype was built. It had a built-in 3.5" floppy disc drive and looked like a Commodore 128.

Elwro factory closed its doors in late eighties. Assets were sold to Siemens.

Thanks to Pawel Kubacki from Poland for information and pictures.

item.description: Discovery system||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISCOVERY SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Discovery system uses the new Sony 3.5'' diskette to save in full safety the programs and data of the Spectrum or Spectrum+. The diskette has a capacity of 180 KB and a second drive can be installed. The commands of the operating system are similar to those of Sinclair Microdrives. The case includes a power supply and various Spectrum expansion connectors. In short, a lot of hardware qualities, but an incomprehensible defect: the data transfer speed is slower than Microdrives, whereas a disk drive is able to be ten times faster than a tape reader. Discovery did not meet success, certainly for this reason, but also because of its high price, not compatible with the Spectrum's young users' purse. </blockquote>

Inside Discovery||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE DISCOVERY</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Metallic case.<br> <b>(2)</b> Centronics parallel printer connector.<br> <b>(3)</b> Spectrum expansion connector.<br> <b>(4)</b> Discovery to Spectrum connector.<br> <b>(5)</b> EPROM memory chip holding drive management routines and OS commands.<br> <b>(6)</b> Sony 3.5'' disc drive. A double side, single density version.<br> <b>(7)</b> A strange location for the power transformer, under the disk drive and not protected against magnetic fields.<br> <b>(8)</b> This empty socket receives a 2 Kb. RAM chip when a second disc drive is installed.<br> <b>(9)</b> 6821 Circuit, in charge of disc drive control.<br> <b>(10)</b> Each disc drive uses an internal RAM area to avoid using Spectrum RAM.<br> <b>(11)</b> Atari standard joystick connector.</blockquote>

Inside Wafadrive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE WAFADRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> The Wafadrive unit includes two specially designed cartridge drives. <br>  <b>(2)</b> Each cartridge drive has its own motor and electronic control system. <br> <b>(3)</b> The Wafadrive offers three expansion ports. Unfortunately, they are not compatible with the Spectrum ones and need special cables. <br> <b>(4)</b> Centronics parallel printer connector. <br> <b>(5)</b> Spectrum expansion connector for additional peripherals. <br> <b>(6)</b> 8 Kb. EPROM holding operating system and Basic drives commands. <br> <b>(7)</b> The Wafadrive is connected to the Spectrum expansion port. It also uses the computer's power supply. <br> <b>(8)</b> Power Leds. <br></blockquote>
Wafadrive cartridge||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> WAFADRIVE CARTRIDGE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

Kempston Joystick Interface||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEMPSTON JOYSTICK INTERFACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Peter says:<br><font color="#666666"> I'm not sure if this was the first joystick interface for the Spectrum but it defined a standard that was never displaced.  Most games carried the words 'Kempston joystick compatible' Says it all really! They later revised the interface to offer 2 joystick connectors </font> <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Peter James for the picture </p></blockquote>

Currah Speech|||Vocal synthesizer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CURRAH SPEECH</strong></font><br><strong>> Vocal synthesizer</strong><br><blockquote>Just type on the keys and the Spectrum "speaks" with two tones, high and low. There is also a sofware support.</blockquote>

Cheetah SpecDrum||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHEETAH SPECDRUM</strong></font><br><blockquote>About the Specdrum, Peter says:<br><font color="#666666"> This was the most fun add-on I ever bought for the Spectrum.  You had to connect it to a phono input on a stereo amp, load up the software and away you went.  You could enter the rhythm in real time or step time and it had 8 sounds it could play at once.  The sound was perfect and still sounds good today.  They released some extra drum kit sounds to expand the Specdrum's sound library, Afro Kit and Electro Kit are the ones I remember and purchased.  I don’t think any Spectrum should be without this Add-on, it rocks!! <br><br> Price: About £30 around 85-86  </font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Peter James for the picture </p></blockquote>

Alphacom 32||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALPHACOM 32</strong></font><br><blockquote>Alphacom 32 is the well-known and the cheaper printer for the Spectrum, offering exactly the same features as the ZX Printer : full Spectrum characters set, 32 char. / line and silver plated thermal paper. Alphacom 32 uses its own power supply. june 84 price : 181 -E- (France).</blockquote>

Floyd 40||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLOYD 40</strong></font><br><blockquote>Floyd 40, from the manufacturer Shiva Marketing, doesn't seem to be very reliable with its very thin plastic case and its wooden paper axis ! However Floyd features are better than Alphacom ones: use of white thermal paper more readable and less expensive, only one cable to connect it to the Spectrum (power and data) and better printing quality. Moreover, Floyd 40 has larger characters set and printing options : double height and width, text printing in the four directions and more advanced and accurate graphic abilities (5 x 7 dots head). On the other hand, the printing is rather slow and the print width doesn't exceed 8 cm.</blockquote>

ZX-81 thermal printer||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ZX-81 THERMAL PRINTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a small thermal printer (of very poor quality !). It can print all the graphical characters of the Spectrum and can print 9 lines of text per inch. It was possible to make a hard copy of the screen thanks to the "Copy" command.  <br><br>  This tiny thermal printer can also be used with the ZX-Spectrum.</blockquote>
ZX thermal printer|||Box|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ZX THERMAL PRINTER</strong></font><br><strong>> Box</strong><br><blockquote></blockquote>

ZX Interface 1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ZX INTERFACE 1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This interface offers an RS232 connector, a Microdrive connector and a network socket to connect up to 64 Spectrums ! <br><br> This marvel cost 895fr in june 84 (France).</blockquote>

Microdrives||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICRODRIVES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sinclair Microdrives for use with the ZX Interface 1. Up to 8 microdrives can be connected. <br><br> Micro-tape Capacity: 80k<br> Speed: 5k/s<br> Average access time: 3,5s<br> Integrated power supply (through computer)<br> Micro-tape price: 79fr<br> <br><br> 940fr (June 84)   </blockquote>

Inside a Microdrive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE A MICRODRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Tape driving roller.<br> <b>(2)</b> Read/write magnetic head, basically the same as a standard tape recorder.<br> <b>(3)</b> Read/write protection switch.<br> <b>(4)</b> Cartridge housing.<br> <b>(5)</b> Power led.<br> <b>(6)</b> Extension connector allowing up to 8 microdrives to be serial connected.<br></blockquote>

Inside a microdrive cartridge||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE A MICRODRIVE CARTRIDGE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The support used in the cartridge is a videotape of 2 mm in width, and 8 meters in length. The video support was chosen for its biggest mechanical resistance. In running mode, the full tape length is covered in about 7 seconds and the information is transferred at 6 Kb. per second (1.5 Kb./sec. for a standard cassette). The recording is made simultaneously on two parallel tracks with a density of 200 bytes per centimeter. The information is organized in sectors of 512 bytes. Any program can be stored or loaded in 15 sec. Maximum. Each cartridge can store up to 100 Kb, but only 85 - 90 are available for the user. </blockquote>

ZX Interface 2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ZX INTERFACE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This interface offers 2 joystick plugs and 1 cartridge slot. <br><br> It cost 351fr in june 84 (France).</blockquote>

Cartridge||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CARTRIDGE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sinclair Cartridge for use with the ZX Interface 2. Very few cartridges were produced (less than 10). <br><br> It cost 185fr in june 84 (France). </blockquote>

Numeric Keypad||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> NUMERIC KEYPAD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This numenic keypad can be used with the Spectrum +2 and Spectrum 128.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
